column1: #text=There are many ways to plant a tree .
#text=One of the least expensive is planting a bare root tree .
#text=I had to chose the right tree for my area and my particular situation .
#text=My local nursery carries only plants suited to our area , but since I bought from a catalog I checked for suitability in a Sunset Garden Book .
#text=I also had to site the tree properly .
#text=It could n't be under power lines , and needed room to spread .
#text=It began as a bare root tree , and it now flowers every early spring , even in our drought .
#text=The hole was wider at the bottom than at the top , and had a cone of firm soil in its center to support the tree .
#text=The hole was about five times as wide across as the tree .
#text=I started the hole with a shovel , but finished by hacking at the soil underground with a spade to undercut the hole and so the roots could get purchase when they started to spread .
#text=I set the bare root tree on the cone I left in the center of the hole and spread out its roots over the cone .
#text=I arranged the roots so the tree would be level , no roots would be exposed , and the upper bark would n't be buried .
#text=Then I nearly filled the hole with soil , firming it lightly by patting it as I went .
#text=When the hole was almost full , I watered slowly , holding the tree straight as the water soaked in .
#text=Then I filled up the hole completely .
#text=finally , I made a ring of soil around the tree , to hold in water when the rainy season ended and I would have to irrigate .

#text=I used no fertilizer or amendments when I planted , because our sandy soil is fairly fertile , and I did n't want to make a dividing line that would encourage the tree to grow only in its tiny pothole of enriched soil .
#text=I wanted it to spread its roots , and it has .
